title: Second language users exhibit shallow morphological processing
text:
Group

Participant group (L1, L2).

ID

Subject unique identifier.

List

Word list.

Target

Target word.

RT

Reaction time (ms).

RT_log

Logged reaction time.

Critical_Filler

Whether the trial is a critical or a filler trial.

Word_Nonword

Whether the word is a real word or a nonce word (only word is present in the data).

Relation_type

Whether the relation type is Unrelated, Constituent, or NonConstituent.

Branching

Whether the trial word is Left-branching or Right-branching.

title: Second language users exhibit shallow morphological processing
text:
Group

Participant group (L1, L2).

ID

Subject unique identifier.

List

Word list.

Target

Target word.

RT

Reaction time (ms).

RT_log

Logged reaction time.

Critical_Filler

Whether the trial is a critical or a filler trial.

Word_Nonword

Whether the word is a real word or a nonce word (only word is present in the data).

Relation_type

Whether the relation type is Unrelated, Constituent, or NonConstituent.

Branching

Whether the trial word is Left-branching or Right-branching.

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Frequentist statistics


P-values: \(P(d|H)\), probability of the difference \(d\) (or a more extreme one) given the hypothesis \(H\).
Neyman-Pearson NHST:

\(H\) is the ‚Äúnull hypothesis‚Äù, to be rejected.
\(\alpha\) level: \(p \ge \alpha\) non-significant difference, \(p < \alpha\) significant difference.
\(\beta\) level: statistical power, probability of detecting a significant difference when there is one.

Null Ritual (Gigerenzer 2004, 2018; Gigerenzer, Krauss, and Vitouch 2004):

\(H\) is a ‚Äúnil hypothesis‚Äù: \(d = 0\), to be rejected.
\(\alpha = 0.05\)
\(\beta = 0.8\)

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Statistical power


Statistical power (\(\beta\) level) is affected by sample size.
One must determine the sample size needed to achieve the desired statistical power. In Null Ritualistic statistics this is 0.8 (or 80% power).
Prospective power analysis.




Two examples

Effect of consonant voicing on vowel duration in mono- vs disyllabic words.
Accuracy in a lexical decision task to investigate shallow morphological representation in L2 speakers.

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Example 1: vowel duration


Data from Coretta (2019b), Coretta (2019a).
‚ÄúVoicing effect‚Äù in Manchester English.
Mono- and di-syllabic nonce words in frame sentences.
Is the voicing effect the same or different in mono- vs disyllabic words?





Use ‚Äúpilot‚Äù data to determine sample size.

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Example 1: the data

library(tidyverse)

eng_s <- readRDS("data/eng_s.rds")
eng_s |> select(speaker, num_syl, word, voicing, v1_duration, speech_rate_c)

# A tibble: 720 √ó 6
   speaker num_syl word   voicing   v1_duration speech_rate_c
   <fct>   <fct>   <fct>  <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>
 1 en02    di      teegus voiced          117.         -0.650
 2 en02    mono    teek   voiceless        95.0        -0.908
 3 en02    mono    teek   voiceless       106.         -0.900
 4 en02    di      tergus voiced          190.         -0.750
 5 en02    di      targus voiced          195.         -0.383
 6 en02    di      teepus voiceless       113.         -0.655
 7 en02    mono    terb   voiced          203.         -0.823
 8 en02    mono    tarp   voiceless       217.         -0.534
 9 en02    di      teegus voiced          120.         -0.571
10 en02    di      terpus voiceless       147.         -0.665
# ‚Ñπ 710 more rows

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
section: Effect of voicing on vowel duration
text: Effect of voicing on vowel duration

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Prospective power analysis: overview


Determine Smallest Meaningful Effect Size (SMES).
Run regression model on pilot or simulated data.
Extend model with simr::extend() and set coefficient to SMES.
Run power calculation with simr::powerCurve().

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Smallest Meaningful Effect Size


The minimum standard deviation for measurements of vowel duration is between 2 to 5 ms (Allen 1978).
Nowak (2006) finds an effect of voicing of 4.5 ms.
Let‚Äôs use an SMES of 5 ms. What does this correspond to as a difference ratio?

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Smallest Meaningful Effect Size (ratios)


x <- seq(50, 300, by = 10)
y <- x + 5

ggplot() +
  aes(x, y/x) +
  geom_point(size = 2) +
  labs(
    x = "Vowel duration",
    y = "Difference ratio"
  )

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Run regression model

dur_lm <- lmer(
  log(v1_duration) ~
    voicing + num_syl + voicing:num_syl + speech_rate_c +
    (voicing | speaker),
  data = eng_s
)

summary(dur_lm)

Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: 
log(v1_duration) ~ voicing + num_syl + voicing:num_syl + speech_rate_c +  
    (voicing | speaker)
   Data: eng_s

REML criterion at convergence: -230

Scaled residuals: 
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-3.3800 -0.5941  0.1648  0.6624  3.1393 

Random effects:
 Groups   Name          Variance  Std.Dev. Corr
 speaker  (Intercept)   0.0181967 0.13490      
          voicingvoiced 0.0004701 0.02168  0.37
 Residual               0.0397878 0.19947      
Number of obs: 720, groups:  speaker, 6

Fixed effects:
                          Estimate Std. Error t value
(Intercept)                4.66722    0.05705  81.816
voicingvoiced              0.17276    0.02281   7.573
num_sylmono                0.08260    0.02308   3.579
speech_rate_c             -0.22902    0.02985  -7.673
voicingvoiced:num_sylmono  0.05501    0.02974   1.850

Correlation of Fixed Effects:
            (Intr) vcngvc nm_syl spch__
voicingvocd -0.029                     
num_sylmono -0.163  0.417              
speech_rt_c  0.011 -0.006  0.412       
vcngvcd:nm_  0.130 -0.652 -0.647 -0.006

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Extend model and set SMES

dur_lm_ext <- extend(dur_lm, along = "speaker", n = 20)

fixef(dur_lm_ext)["voicingvoiced:num_sylmono"] <- 0.03
fixef(dur_lm_ext)

              (Intercept)             voicingvoiced               num_sylmono 
               4.66722417                0.17276388                0.08260109 
            speech_rate_c voicingvoiced:num_sylmono 
              -0.22902490                0.03000000

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Run power analysis

library(simr)

dur_lm_pow <- powerCurve(
  dur_lm_ext,
  fixed("voicing:num_syl"),
  along = "speaker",
  breaks = c(50, 70, 100)
)

print(dur_lm_pow)



Power for predictor 'voicing:num_syl', (95% confidence interval),
by number of levels in speaker:
     50: 83.30% (80.84, 85.56) - 6000 rows
     70: 92.90% (91.13, 94.41) - 8400 rows
    100: 98.90% (98.04, 99.45) - 12000 rows

Time elapsed: 1 h 12 m 47 s

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Power curve plot

plot(dur_lm_pow)

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Example 2: accuracy


Data from Song et al. (2020).
Shallow morphological representation in L2 speakers.
Lexical decision task: Is the word a real English word or not?
Priming paradigm:

Prime: prolong (unrelated), unkind (constituent), kindness (non-constituent).
Target: unkindness ([un-kind]-ness, not un-[kind-ness]).

Constituent vs non-constituent accuracy in L2 speakers.

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Example 2: the data

shallow_s <- readRDS("data/shallow_s.rds")
shallow_s

text: Accuracy by relation type

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Smallest Meaningful Effect Size (log-odds)


I have no idea‚Ä¶
Say -0.2 (log-odds).

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text: Smallest Meaningful Effect Size (probability)

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Run regression model

sha_lm <- glmer(
  ACC ~ Relation_type + (Relation_type | ID),
  family = binomial,
  data = shallow_s
)

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
Summary


Determine Smallest Meaningful Effect Size (SMES).
Run regression model on pilot or simulated data.
Extend model with simr::extend() and set coefficient to SMES.
Run power calculation with simr::powerCurve().




Questions?

title: proPower: Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models
text:
References


Allen, George D. 1978. ‚ÄúVowel Duration Measurement: A Reliability Study.‚Äù The Journal of the Acoustical Society of America 63 (4): 11761185. https://doi.org/10.1121/1.381826.


Coretta, Stefano. 2019a. ‚ÄúCompensatory Aspects of the Effect of Voicing on Vowel Duration in English [Data V1.0.0].‚Äù https://doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/EP8WB.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî. 2019b. ‚ÄúTemporal (in)stability in English Monosyllabic and Disyllabic Words: Insights on the Effect of Voicing on Vowel Duration.‚Äù https://doi.org/10.31219/osf.io/jvwa8.


Gigerenzer, Gerd. 2004. ‚ÄúMindless Statistics.‚Äù The Journal of Socio-Economics 33 (5): 587606. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socec.2004.09.033.


‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî. 2018. ‚ÄúStatistical Rituals: The Replication Delusion and How We Got There.‚Äù Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science 1 (2): 198218. https://doi.org/10.1177/2515245918771329.


Gigerenzer, Gerd, Stefan Krauss, and Oliver Vitouch. 2004. ‚ÄúThe Null Ritual. What You Always Wanted to Know about Significance Testing but Were Afraid to Ask.‚Äù In, 391408.


Nowak, Pawel. 2006. ‚ÄúVowel Reduction in Polish.‚Äù PhD thesis.


Song, Yoonsang, Youngah Do, Arthur L. Thompson, Eileen R. Waegemaekers, and Jongbong Lee. 2020. ‚ÄúSecond Language Users Exhibit Shallow Morphological Processing.‚Äù Studies in Second Language Acquisition 42 (5): 1121‚Äì36. https://doi.org/10.1017/s0272263120000170.

title: 02-shallow
text:
library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.1     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.0.2     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggeffects)
library(simr)

Loading required package: lme4
Loading required package: Matrix

Attaching package: 'Matrix'

The following objects are masked from 'package:tidyr':

    expand, pack, unpack


Attaching package: 'simr'

The following object is masked from 'package:lme4':

    getData

The following object is masked from 'package:stringr':

    fixed



shallow <- read_csv("data/song2020/shallow.csv")

Rows: 6500 Columns: 11
‚îÄ‚îÄ Column specification ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Delimiter: ","
chr (8): Group, ID, List, Target, Critical_Filler, Word_Nonword, Relation_ty...
dbl (3): ACC, RT, logRT

‚Ñπ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
‚Ñπ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

shallow_l2 <- shallow |> 
  filter(Group == "L2", Branching == "Left")

set.seed(9823)
shallow_s <- shallow_l2 |> 
  distinct(ID) |> 
  slice_sample(n = 10) |> 
  inner_join(shallow_l2, by = "ID") |> 
  filter(Branching == "Left") |> 
  droplevels()

saveRDS(shallow_s, "data/shallow_s.rds")
unique(shallow_s$ID)

[10] "L2_26"



sha_lm <- glmer(
  ACC ~ Relation_type + (Relation_type | ID),
  family = binomial,
  data = shallow_s
)

sha_lm_ext <- extend(sha_lm_2, along = "ID", n = 1000)
fixef(sha_lm_ext)["Relation_typeNonConstituent"] <- -0.2

fi <- "cache/sha_lm_pow.rds"

if (file.exists(fi)) {
  sha_lm_pow <- readRDS(fi)
} else {
  suppressMessages(
    sha_lm_pow <- powerCurve(sha_lm_ext, fixed("Relation_typeNonConstituent"), along = "ID")
  )
  # The following is needed in this case probably because of a bug in powerCurve()
  sha_lm_pow[["xval"]] <- sha_lm_pow[["nlevels"]]
  saveRDS(sha_lm_pow, fi)
}


print(sha_lm_pow)

title: Prepare data
text:
library(tidyverse)

‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ

‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.1     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.4     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.0.2     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors

library(ggeffects)
library(simr)

Loading required package: lme4
Loading required package: Matrix

Attaching package: 'Matrix'

The following objects are masked from 'package:tidyr':

    expand, pack, unpack


Attaching package: 'simr'

The following object is masked from 'package:lme4':

    getData

The following object is masked from 'package:stringr':

    fixed

library(coretta2019eng)
data("eng_durations")


set.seed(9872)
eng_s <- eng_durations |>
  distinct(speaker) |> 
  slice_sample(n = 6) |> 
  inner_join(eng_durations, by = "speaker") |> 
  droplevels()
unique(eng_s$speaker)

[1] en02 en11 en01 en04 en03 en07
Levels: en01 en02 en03 en04 en07 en11

saveRDS(eng_s, "data/eng_s.rds")


eng_s |> 
  ggplot(aes(voicing, v1_duration)) +
  geom_jitter() +
  facet_grid(cols = vars(num_syl))









dur_lm <- lmer(
  log(v1_duration) ~ voicing + num_syl + voicing:num_syl + speech_rate_c + (voicing | speaker),
  data = eng_s
)


summary(dur_lm)

Linear mixed model fit by REML ['lmerMod']
Formula: 
log(v1_duration) ~ voicing + num_syl + voicing:num_syl + speech_rate_c +  
    (voicing | speaker)
   Data: eng_s

REML criterion at convergence: -230

Scaled residuals: 
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-3.3800 -0.5941  0.1648  0.6624  3.1393 

Random effects:
 Groups   Name          Variance  Std.Dev. Corr
 speaker  (Intercept)   0.0181967 0.13490      
          voicingvoiced 0.0004701 0.02168  0.37
 Residual               0.0397878 0.19947      
Number of obs: 720, groups:  speaker, 6

Fixed effects:
                          Estimate Std. Error t value
(Intercept)                4.66722    0.05705  81.816
voicingvoiced              0.17276    0.02281   7.573
num_sylmono                0.08260    0.02308   3.579
speech_rate_c             -0.22902    0.02985  -7.673
voicingvoiced:num_sylmono  0.05501    0.02974   1.850

Correlation of Fixed Effects:
            (Intr) vcngvc nm_syl spch__
voicingvocd -0.029                     
num_sylmono -0.163  0.417              
speech_rt_c  0.011 -0.006  0.412       
vcngvcd:nm_  0.130 -0.652 -0.647 -0.006



ggpredict(dur_lm, c("voicing", "num_syl"))

Model has log-transformed response. Back-transforming predictions to
  original response scale. Standard errors are still on the transformed
  scale.


# Predicted values of v1_duration

num_syl: di

voicing   | Predicted |         95% CI
--------------------------------------
voiceless |    110.79 |  99.01, 123.96
voiced    |    131.68 | 116.82, 148.43

num_syl: mono

voicing   | Predicted |         95% CI
--------------------------------------
voiceless |    120.33 | 107.53, 134.64
voiced    |    151.11 | 134.06, 170.32

Adjusted for:
* speech_rate_c = -0.18
*       speaker = 0 (population-level)



dur_lm_ext <- extend(dur_lm, along = "speaker", n = 100)
fixef(dur_lm_ext)["voicingvoiced:num_sylmono"] <- 0.03

fi <- "cache/dur_lm_pow.rds"

if (file.exists(fi)) {
  dur_lm_pow <- readRDS(fi)
} else {
  suppressMessages(
    dur_lm_pow <- powerCurve(dur_lm_ext, fixed("voicing:num_syl"), along = "speaker", breaks = c(50, 70, 100)) 
  )
  saveRDS(dur_lm_pow, fi)
}


print(dur_lm_pow)

Power for predictor 'voicing:num_syl', (95% confidence interval),
by number of levels in speaker:
     50: 83.30% (80.84, 85.56) - 6000 rows
     70: 92.90% (91.13, 94.41) - 8400 rows
    100: 98.90% (98.04, 99.45) - 12000 rows

Time elapsed: 1 h 12 m 47 s

plot(dur_lm_pow)









x <- seq(50, 200, by = 10)
y <- x + 5
plot(x, y/x)

title: proPower
text:
This is the website of the workshop Prospective power analyses for frequentist regression models, part of the STeW series (Statistical Training Workshops) of the Linguistics and English Language department of the University of Edinburgh.
The slides are linked in the main menu and you can find data and code in the GitHub repository: https://github.com/stefanocoretta/proPower.







Level
üü† Intermediate


Description
You will learn how to perform prospective power analyses for regression/linear models fitted with the frequentist lme4 package. Power analyses are a necessary (albeit always neglected) component of frequentist analyses, since they help the researcher determine the required sample size. Much of the replicability crisis we are facing is due to lack of statistical power (aka low sample sizes) in virtually all published studies.


Prerequisites
Need to be familiar with regression/linear models in R including models with random effects and binomial/Bernoulli (aka logistic) regressions.

title: About
